paragraphs.name: ef03
paragraphs.text: In encountering these ideas, I realized that my assessment practices were bogged down by an overemphasis on scores and my total domination of assessment and grading. This year, I changed my approach, using feedback and revisions only, without entering a letter grade until the end of each term. At that point, I allow students an opportunity to evaluate their overall performance using statements from my Descriptive Grading Criteria (adapted from Ken O’Connor’s 15 Fixes for Broken Grades). Upon completing this process, they sign up to conference with me personally, or complete a linked letter or video explaining the grade they believe they deserve.

For others, gradeless means without grades, that is, avoiding the damaging and demotivating effects of grades entirely. These teachers are trying to put the focus squarely on learning, eliminating grades in favor of feedback and growth. Some may even work in schools that have replaced traditional report cards altogether, using portfolios or descriptive evaluations instead. I experienced the latter at University of Michigan’s Residential College back in the 90’s. (If you’ve got an hour or two, I can show you my report card!)
paragraphs.name: 022b

paragraphs.text: So for anybody in that world reading this, please accept my encouragement to keep on doing what you’re doing, and I hope that we profs can experiment and figure out some best practices that K-12 people can use, so we can make mistakes for you. :)
paragraphs.name: f906
7e73
paragraphs.text: For some of us, the word gradeless means to grade less, that is, limiting the impact of grades within the context of current constraints. Some are just trying to get away from toxic assessment and grading practices, like assessments with no opportunity to redo or retake or zeroes on the mathematically disproportionate 100-point scale.

Great article, Arthur. I’m a higher ed person who got turned on to standards-based grading by some of my colleagues a couple of years ago and while I’ve had some bumps in the road getting my system where I want it, it’s been great, and I am never going back. It takes my students about 2–3 weeks to realize the benefits of the system and then they too…

Rather than standards for each discipline, the curriculum is built around themes (see the IB curriculum for an example.) All activities begin with a large question, which then branches off into questions each learner wants…

d7e11fc4739b.title: Are we really trying to create better, more informed learners?

paragraphs.text: Are we really trying to create better, more informed learners? Or are we trying to achieve “equality” by subjectively determining who are the top performers? Or just deciding that everyone did equally well.
paragraphs.name: 38b2

paragraphs.text: Even if you picked door #1, I can see the vast potential for abuse.
paragraphs.name: 169a

virtuals.subtitle: Even if you picked door #1, I can see the vast potential for abuse.

697037f15bf1.title: My sister went to Urban Academy, an alternative high school in NYC, where they used a portfolio…

paragraphs.text: My sister went to Urban Academy, an alternative high school in NYC, where they used a portfolio system rather than traditional tests and grades. She really enjoyed the experience and remains in touch with the teachers and administrators, who still provide mentoring to her.
paragraphs.name: 245f

paragraphs.text: That’d be great, Robert. Especially since one of the more common objections to this approach is “We won’t be preparing them for what they’ll experience in college.” As I commented earlier, I don’t want to prepare kids for the educational malpractice they’ll encounter later!
paragraphs.name: d9b8

73273b8a5d60.title: Yes! This is the holy grail of education.

paragraphs.text: Yes! This is the holy grail of education. With small enough class sizes and a focus on process over product teachers can provide the qualitatively rich feedback that helps students learn and grow.

paragraphs.text: I came across this research when I was training to teach and applied it a lot in my earlier years of teaching. Of course it works. Why wouldn’t it? After all, it is how children first start to learn, so stuffing grades and levels in when they go to school is nothing more than an arbitrary act that serves the teacher (system) more than the child.

paragraphs.text: Great piece. I’ve been teaching 30 years, and I don’t grade at all. I focus on the arc of learning. Turns out it’s all about empathy. Put students in connected environments, and give them age appropriate meaning with authentic goals, and learning soars.
